verses.verse: (1 Peter goeth into the Temple with John, 2 healeth the cripple.9 To the people gathered together to see the miracle,12 he expoundeth the mystery of our salvation through Christ,14 accusing their ingratitude,19 and requiring the repentance.) Now (Christ in healing a man that was born lame, and well known to all men, both in place and time very famous, by the hands of his Apostles, doth partly confirm them which believed, and partly also calleth others to believe.) Peter and John went up together into the Temple, at the ninth hour of prayer.
And a certain man which was a cripple from his mother’s womb was carried, whom they laid daily at the gate of the Temple called Beautiful, to ask alms of them that entered into the Temple,
Who seeing Peter and John, that they would enter into the Temple, desiring to receive an alms.
And Peter earnestly beholding him with John, said, Look on us.
And he (Both with heart and eyes.) gave heed unto them, trusting to receive some thing of them.
Then said Peter, Silver and gold have I none, but such as I have, that give I thee: In the Name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, rise up and walk.
And he took him by the right hand, and lifted him up, and immediately his feet and ankle bones received strength.
And he leaped up, stood, and walked, and entered with them into the temple, walking and leaping, and praising God.
And all the people saw him walk, and praising God.
And they knew him, that it was he which sat for the alms at the Beautiful gate of the Temple: and they were amazed, and sore astonied at that which was come unto him.

¶ And as the cripple which was healed, (Either because he loved them, who had healed him: or because he feared that if he once let them go out of his sight, he should be lame again.) held Peter and John, all the people ran amazed unto them in the porch which is called Solomon’s.

(Miracles are appointed to convince the unbelievers, and therefore they do wickedly abuse them, who standeth amazed either at the miracles themselves, or at the instruments and means which it pleaseth God to use, take an occasion to establish idolatry and superstition by that, which God hath provided for the knowledge of his true worship, that is, Christianity.) So when Peter saw it, he answered unto the people, Ye men of Israel, why marvel ye at this? or why look ye so steadfastly on us, as though by our own power or godliness, we had made this man go?

The God of Abraham, and Isaac, and Jacob, the (Cross references: : Acts 5:30) God of our fathers hath glorified his Son Jesus, whom ye betrayed, and denied in the presence of Pilate, when he had judged him to be delivered.
But ye denied the Holy one and the just, and desired a murderer to be given you,
And killed the Lord (Who hath life in himself, and giveth life to others.) of life, whom God hath raised from the dead, whereof we are witnesses.

And his Name hath made this man sound, whom ye see and know, through faith in his Name: (Because he believed on him being raised from the dead, whose Name he heard of by us.) and the faith which is by him, hath given to him this perfect health of his whole body in the presence of you all.

(It is best of all to receive Christ so soon as he is offered unto us: but such as have neglected so great a benefit through man’s weakness, have yet repentance for a means. As for the ignominy of the cross, we have to set against that, the decree and purpose of God, foretold by the Prophets, of Christ, how that first of all he should be crucified here upon earth, and then he should appear from heaven the judge and restorer of all things, that all believers might be saved, and all unbelievers utterly perish.) And now brethren, I know that through ignorance ye did it, as did also your governors.

But those things, which God before had showed (Though there were many Prophets, yet he speaketh but of one mouth, to show unto us the consent and agreement of the Prophets.) by the mouth of all his Prophets, that Christ should suffer, he hath thus fulfilled.
Amend your lives therefore, and turn, that your sins may be put away, when the time of refreshing shall come from the presence of the Lord.
And he shall send Jesus Christ, which before was preached unto you.
(Or, be taken up into heaven.) Whom the heaven must contain until the time that all things be restored, which God had spoken by the mouth of all his holy Prophets since the world began.

(Deut. 18:15; Acts 7:37) For Moses said unto the Fathers, The Lord your God shall raise up unto you (This promise was of an excellent and singular Prophet.) a Prophet, even of your brethren, like unto me: ye shall hear him in all things whatsoever he shall say unto you.
For it shall be that every person which shall not hear that Prophet, shall be destroyed out of the people.
Also all the Prophets (At what time the kingdom of Israel was established.) from Samuel, and thenceforth as many as have spoken, have likewise foretold of these days.

(The Jews that believe are the first begotten in the kingdom of God.) Ye are the (For whom the Prophets were specially appointed.) children of the Prophets, and of the covenant, which God hath made unto our fathers, saying to Abraham, (Gen. 12:3; Gal. 3:8) Even in thy seed shall all the kindreds of the earth be blessed.

First unto you hath God (Given to the world, or raised from the dead, and advanced to his kingdom.) raised up his Son Jesus, and him he hath sent to bless you, in turning everyone of you from your iniquities.
